original_case_data.name: Lankford v. Sherman
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Plaintiffs are Missouri residents who depend on Medicaid for durable medical equipment (DME).
original_case_data.summary:
On August 29, 2005, seven low-income Missouri residents who received health coverage through Medicaid filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri. The plaintiffs sued the State of Missouri under the Medicaid Act, pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 1983 and the Supremacy Clause. The plaintiffs, represented by an array of public interest organizations, sought declaratory and injunctive relief, asking the court to enjoin Missouri from enforcing an emergency Medicaid regulation that would deny plaintiffs access to durable medical equipment (DME). The plaintiffs claimed that the emergency regulation, eliminating coverage of DME for most categorically-needy Medicaid recipients in the state, violated the Medicaid Act's comparability requirements and reasonable standards provisions.

As background, DME includes a wide variety of medical devices and equipment, including wheelchairs, prosthetics, orthopedic devices and hospital beds. Before 2005, Missouri provided DME as a stand-alone benefit to all recipients of Medicaid in the state. However, due to budget constraints, Missouri eliminated coverage of DME except for residents who are needy children, blind, or pregnant. In September 2005, the state promulgated an emergency regulation that reinstated coverage of certain DME items for all Medicaid recipients -- while at the same time extended coverage of additional items only to recipients who are blind, pregnant, needy children or those receiving home health care. The plaintiffs, who did not fall into those categories, were unable to obtain coverage for previously covered DME. Rather than challenging the statute, the plaintiffs argued that the emergency regulation impermissibly extended DME coverage to blind recipients but not others -- in violation of federal law.

On September 13, 2005, the court (Judge Whipple) denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. In evaluating the plaintiff's argument, Judge Whipple reasoned that the Missouri emergency regulations likely did not violate the comparability requirement of the Medicaid Act. Judge Whipple concluded that the plaintiffs had other ways of obtaining DME through the state's Medicaid program. Further, he noted that Missouri had filed for a waiver from the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to permit it to provide DME services to the blind (but not other categorically need persons such as the plaintiffs). The plaintiffs appealed the District Court's decision to the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals.

On June 22, 2006, the Eighth Circuit (Judge Benton) vacated and remanded the District Court's decision, finding that the state DME regulation was likely preempted by the Supremacy Clause. (Lankford v. Sherman, 451 F.3d 496 (8th Cir. 2006)). The Eighth Circuit determined, in line with the District Court's conclusion, that Missouri's provision of DME did not violate the Medicaid Act's comparability requirement. After HHS/CMS denied the waiver, Missouri decided to cover DME for the blind using solely state (and no federal) funds, meaning that it need not comply with the federal requirement. For the same reasons, the court concluded that the provision of DME services did not violate the reasonable standards requirement. The court further concluded that the plaintiffs did not have a private right of action under 1983 to enforce Medicaid's reasonable-standards provision.

The Eighth Circuit concluded that Missouri's DME regulations conflicted with the federal regulations that implement Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement; thus, the regulations violated the Supremacy Clause. The plaintiffs had argued that the state regulation was unreasonable because it failed to provide sufficient DME services to meet Medicaid's basic objectives and the state's proposed alternatives to obtain the necessary DME were insufficient. The court agreed, concluding that the plaintiffs established a likelihood that they would prevail on the merits of their preemption claim pertaining to the reasonable-standards requirement. The court explained that because likelihood of success on the merits is only one of the four factors in determining whether to grant a preliminary injunction and the district court failed to address the other facts, the case should be remanded.

On March 2, 2007, Judge Whipple, on remand, granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and for a preliminary injunction to enjoin enforcement of Missouri's emergency Medicaid regulations that essentially eliminated the plaintiffs' access through Medicaid of DME. Judge Whipple ordered the state to amend its current DME program to comply with Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement, thus remedying the preemption problem that the Eighth Circuit found.

On June 1, 2008, the defendants informed the court that on May 18, 2007, the Missouri General Assembly had passed a bill that covered all medically necessary DME. As such, defendants asked the court to declare that they were in compliance with the court's March 2 order.

On January 23, 2008, Judge Whipple declared that the defendants were in compliance with that order. He noted, however, that the only issue before the court was the legality of Missouri's 2005 emergency regulations. By eliminating that proposed regulatory scheme, Missouri complied with the order. However, the court was not deciding whether the state's subsequent legislative action in May 2007 conformed with the reasonable-standards requirement.

Because Judge Whipple found the defendants in compliance with the March 2, 2007 order, the case is closed.
original_case_data.summary_short: Low-income Missouri residents sued the state to enjoin enforcement of emergency medicaid regulations that would have largely eliminated coverage of durable medical equipment under Medicaid for all but a small class of residents. While the district court denied the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals determined that the plaintiffs were likely to prevail on their Supremacy Clause argument; following the Eighth Circuit's ruling, the district court granted the preliminary injunction.

1.transformed_text:
On August 29, 2005, seven low-income Missouri Medicaid recipients filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri against the State of Missouri under the Medicaid Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and the Supremacy Clause. Represented by public interest organizations, plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to enjoin enforcement of an emergency Medicaid regulation that denied them access to durable medical equipment (DME). They asserted the regulation, which eliminated DME coverage for most categorically-needy Medicaid recipients, violated the Medicaid Act's comparability requirements and reasonable standards provisions.

DME encompasses various medical devices and equipment, such as wheelchairs, prosthetics, orthopedic devices, and hospital beds. Prior to 2005, Missouri provided DME as a stand-alone benefit to all Medicaid recipients. Due to budget constraints, Missouri eliminated DME coverage except for needy children, blind, or pregnant residents. In September 2005, the state promulgated an emergency regulation reinstating coverage of certain DME items for all Medicaid recipients, while extending additional items only to those who are blind, pregnant, needy children, or receiving home health care. Plaintiffs, not falling into these categories, were unable to obtain coverage for previously covered DME. They argued the emergency regulation impermissibly extended DME coverage to blind recipients but not others, violating federal law, rather than challenging the underlying statute.

On September 13, 2005, Judge Whipple denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. The court reasoned that Missouri's emergency regulations likely did not violate the Medicaid Act's comparability requirement, concluding plaintiffs had alternative avenues for obtaining DME. Judge Whipple also noted Missouri had sought a waiver from the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to provide DME services to the blind, excluding other categorically needy persons like the plaintiffs. Plaintiffs appealed to the Eighth Circuit.

On June 22, 2006, the Eighth Circuit (Judge Benton) vacated and remanded the District Court's decision, finding the state DME regulation was likely preempted by the Supremacy Clause. (Lankford v. Sherman, 451 F.3d 496 (8th Cir. 2006)). The Eighth Circuit affirmed the District Court's conclusion that Missouri's DME provision did not violate the Medicaid Act's comparability requirement. After HHS/CMS denied the waiver, Missouri opted to cover DME for the blind using solely state funds, thereby avoiding federal compliance requirements. The court also held plaintiffs lacked a private right of action under § 1983 to enforce Medicaid's reasonable-standards provision.

The Eighth Circuit concluded that Missouri's DME regulations conflicted with federal regulations implementing Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement, thus violating the Supremacy Clause. Plaintiffs had argued the state regulation was unreasonable, failing to provide sufficient DME services to meet Medicaid's basic objectives, and that proposed state alternatives were insufficient. The court agreed, finding plaintiffs established a likelihood of prevailing on their preemption claim regarding the reasonable-standards requirement. The case was remanded because the likelihood of success on the merits is only one of four factors for a preliminary injunction, and the district court failed to address the others.

On March 2, 2007, on remand, Judge Whipple granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and a preliminary injunction, enjoining enforcement of Missouri's emergency Medicaid regulations that eliminated plaintiffs' Medicaid access to DME. The court ordered the state to amend its DME program to comply with Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement, remedying the preemption issue identified by the Eighth Circuit.

On June 1, 2008, defendants informed the court that the Missouri General Assembly had passed a bill on May 18, 2007, covering all medically necessary DME, and sought a declaration of compliance with the court's March 2 order.

On January 23, 2008, Judge Whipple declared defendants in compliance with the March 2, 2007 order. He noted the only issue before the court was the legality of Missouri's 2005 emergency regulations, and by eliminating that proposed regulatory scheme, Missouri complied. However, the court was not deciding whether the state's subsequent legislative action in May 2007 conformed with the reasonable-standards requirement.

Because Judge Whipple found the defendants in compliance with the March 2, 2007 order, the case is closed.

2.transformed_text:
On August 29, 2005, seven low-income Missouri Medicaid recipients filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri against the State of Missouri under the Medicaid Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and the Supremacy Clause. Represented by public interest organizations, plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to enjoin enforcement of an emergency Medicaid regulation denying them access to durable medical equipment (DME). They asserted the regulation, which eliminated DME coverage for most categorically-needy Medicaid recipients, violated the Medicaid Act's comparability requirements and reasonable standards provisions.

Durable medical equipment (DME) was previously a stand-alone benefit for all Missouri Medicaid recipients. In 2005, due to budget constraints, Missouri eliminated most DME coverage. An emergency regulation then reinstated certain DME items for all, but extended additional items only to specific categories (blind, pregnant, needy children, or home health care). Plaintiffs, excluded from these categories, were unable to obtain previously covered DME, arguing this regulation impermissibly favored some recipients, violating federal law.

On September 13, 2005, the District Court (Judge Whipple) denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. The court found Missouri's emergency regulations likely did not violate the Medicaid Act's comparability requirement, noting plaintiffs had alternative DME access and that Missouri sought a waiver from HHS/CMS for blind-specific DME coverage. Plaintiffs appealed.

On June 22, 2006, the Eighth Circuit (Judge Benton) vacated and remanded, finding the state DME regulation likely preempted by the Supremacy Clause (Lankford v. Sherman, 451 F.3d 496 (8th Cir. 2006)). The appellate court affirmed the District Court's conclusion that Missouri's DME provision did not violate the Medicaid Act's comparability requirement. After HHS/CMS denied the waiver, Missouri opted to cover DME for the blind using solely state funds, which the court found did not violate the reasonable standards requirement. Plaintiffs also lacked a private right of action under § 1983 to enforce Medicaid's reasonable-standards provision.

However, the Eighth Circuit concluded that Missouri's DME regulations conflicted with federal regulations implementing Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement, thus violating the Supremacy Clause. The court agreed with plaintiffs that the state regulation was unreasonable, failing to provide sufficient DME services or adequate alternatives, establishing a likelihood of prevailing on their preemption claim. Remand was necessary as the District Court had only addressed one of four preliminary injunction factors.

On remand, the District Court (Judge Whipple) granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and a preliminary injunction on March 2, 2007. The court enjoined enforcement of Missouri's emergency Medicaid regulations, ordering the state to amend its DME program to comply with Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement and remedy the preemption issue.

On June 1, 2008, defendants informed the court that the Missouri General Assembly had passed a bill on May 18, 2007, covering all medically necessary DME, and sought a declaration of compliance with the March 2, 2007 order.

On January 23, 2008, Judge Whipple declared defendants in compliance with the March 2, 2007 order. He noted that compliance stemmed from the elimination of the 2005 emergency regulations, which was the sole issue before the court. The court clarified it was not ruling on whether the state's subsequent May 2007 legislative action conformed with the reasonable-standards requirement.

Because Judge Whipple found the defendants in compliance with the March 2, 2007 order, the case is closed.

3.transformed_text:
This litigation concluded with the State of Missouri being found in compliance with a court order requiring it to amend its Medicaid durable medical equipment (DME) program after its emergency regulations were found to violate federal law.

*   Seven low-income Missouri Medicaid recipients filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri against the State of Missouri under the Medicaid Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and the Supremacy Clause. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to enjoin enforcement of an emergency Medicaid regulation that eliminated DME coverage for most categorically-needy recipients, asserting it violated the Medicaid Act's comparability requirements and reasonable standards provisions. The District Court initially denied a preliminary injunction, finding the emergency regulations likely did not violate the comparability requirement, noting alternative DME access and a waiver application to HHS/CMS.

*   On appeal, the Eighth Circuit vacated and remanded, concluding Missouri's DME regulation was likely preempted by the Supremacy Clause, as it conflicted with federal regulations implementing Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement. The appellate court affirmed the District Court's finding that Missouri's DME provision did not violate the Medicaid Act's comparability requirement. It also determined plaintiffs lacked a private right of action under § 1983 to enforce Medicaid's reasonable-standards provision, and that Missouri's state-funded DME coverage for the blind did not violate the reasonable standards requirement.

*   On remand, the District Court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and a preliminary injunction, enjoining enforcement of Missouri's emergency Medicaid regulations. The court ordered the state to amend its DME program to comply with Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement and remedy the preemption issue identified by the Eighth Circuit.

*   Defendants subsequently informed the court that the Missouri General Assembly had passed a bill covering all medically necessary DME. The District Court then declared defendants in compliance with its March 2, 2007 order, clarifying that compliance stemmed from the elimination of the 2005 emergency regulations, which was the sole issue before the court, and not a ruling on whether the state's subsequent 2007 legislative action conformed with the reasonable-standards requirement. The case was then closed.

*   **Who Sued Who?** Seven low-income Missouri Medicaid recipients sued the State of Missouri under the Medicaid Act, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and the Supremacy Clause.
*   **Why?** Plaintiffs sought to enjoin enforcement of an emergency Medicaid regulation that eliminated durable medical equipment (DME) coverage for most categorically-needy recipients. They asserted it violated the Medicaid Act's comparability requirements and reasonable standards provisions, claiming preemption.
*   **What Happened?** The District Court initially denied a preliminary injunction, finding the emergency regulations likely did not violate the comparability requirement. On appeal, the Eighth Circuit vacated and remanded, concluding Missouri's DME regulation was likely preempted by the Supremacy Clause, conflicting with federal reasonable-standards regulations. The appellate court affirmed no comparability violation and found no private right of action under § 1983 for reasonable-standards. On remand, the District Court granted plaintiffs' summary judgment and preliminary injunction, enjoining the emergency regulations and ordering the state to amend its DME program to comply with reasonable-standards and remedy preemption. Defendants then informed the court of a new bill covering all medically necessary DME. The District Court declared defendants in compliance with its March 2, 2007 order, clarifying compliance stemmed from the elimination of the 2005 emergency regulations, not a ruling on the 2007 legislative action's conformity. The case was closed.

0.text:
On August 29, 2005, seven low-income Missouri residents who received health coverage through Medicaid filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri. The plaintiffs sued the State of Missouri under the Medicaid Act, pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 1983 and the Supremacy Clause. The plaintiffs, represented by an array of public interest organizations, sought declaratory and injunctive relief, asking the court to enjoin Missouri from enforcing an emergency Medicaid regulation that would deny plaintiffs access to durable medical equipment (DME). The plaintiffs claimed that the emergency regulation, eliminating coverage of DME for most categorically-needy Medicaid recipients in the state, violated the Medicaid Act's comparability requirements and reasonable standards provisions.

As background, DME includes a wide variety of medical devices and equipment, including wheelchairs, prosthetics, orthopedic devices and hospital beds. Before 2005, Missouri provided DME as a stand-alone benefit to all recipients of Medicaid in the state. However, due to budget constraints, Missouri eliminated coverage of DME except for residents who are needy children, blind, or pregnant. In September 2005, the state promulgated an emergency regulation that reinstated coverage of certain DME items for all Medicaid recipients -- while at the same time extended coverage of additional items only to recipients who are blind, pregnant, needy children or those receiving home health care. The plaintiffs, who did not fall into those categories, were unable to obtain coverage for previously covered DME. Rather than challenging the statute, the plaintiffs argued that the emergency regulation impermissibly extended DME coverage to blind recipients but not others -- in violation of federal law.

On September 13, 2005, the court (Judge Whipple) denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. In evaluating the plaintiff's argument, Judge Whipple reasoned that the Missouri emergency regulations likely did not violate the comparability requirement of the Medicaid Act. Judge Whipple concluded that the plaintiffs had other ways of obtaining DME through the state's Medicaid program. Further, he noted that Missouri had filed for a waiver from the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to permit it to provide DME services to the blind (but not other categorically need persons such as the plaintiffs). The plaintiffs appealed the District Court's decision to the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals.

On June 22, 2006, the Eighth Circuit (Judge Benton) vacated and remanded the District Court's decision, finding that the state DME regulation was likely preempted by the Supremacy Clause. (Lankford v. Sherman, 451 F.3d 496 (8th Cir. 2006)). The Eighth Circuit determined, in line with the District Court's conclusion, that Missouri's provision of DME did not violate the Medicaid Act's comparability requirement. After HHS/CMS denied the waiver, Missouri decided to cover DME for the blind using solely state (and no federal) funds, meaning that it need not comply with the federal requirement. For the same reasons, the court concluded that the provision of DME services did not violate the reasonable standards requirement. The court further concluded that the plaintiffs did not have a private right of action under 1983 to enforce Medicaid's reasonable-standards provision.

The Eighth Circuit concluded that Missouri's DME regulations conflicted with the federal regulations that implement Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement; thus, the regulations violated the Supremacy Clause. The plaintiffs had argued that the state regulation was unreasonable because it failed to provide sufficient DME services to meet Medicaid's basic objectives and the state's proposed alternatives to obtain the necessary DME were insufficient. The court agreed, concluding that the plaintiffs established a likelihood that they would prevail on the merits of their preemption claim pertaining to the reasonable-standards requirement. The court explained that because likelihood of success on the merits is only one of the four factors in determining whether to grant a preliminary injunction and the district court failed to address the other facts, the case should be remanded.

On March 2, 2007, Judge Whipple, on remand, granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and for a preliminary injunction to enjoin enforcement of Missouri's emergency Medicaid regulations that essentially eliminated the plaintiffs' access through Medicaid of DME. Judge Whipple ordered the state to amend its current DME program to comply with Medicaid's reasonable-standards requirement, thus remedying the preemption problem that the Eighth Circuit found.

On June 1, 2008, the defendants informed the court that on May 18, 2007, the Missouri General Assembly had passed a bill that covered all medically necessary DME. As such, defendants asked the court to declare that they were in compliance with the court's March 2 order.

On January 23, 2008, Judge Whipple declared that the defendants were in compliance with that order. He noted, however, that the only issue before the court was the legality of Missouri's 2005 emergency regulations. By eliminating that proposed regulatory scheme, Missouri complied with the order. However, the court was not deciding whether the state's subsequent legislative action in May 2007 conformed with the reasonable-standards requirement.

Because Judge Whipple found the defendants in compliance with the March 2, 2007 order, the case is closed.

On August 29, 2005, seven low-income Missouri residents on Medicaid filed a lawsuit in a federal court in Missouri. They sued the State of Missouri, arguing that a state rule violated the federal Medicaid Act and the U.S. Constitution's Supremacy Clause. These plaintiffs, represented by public interest groups, asked the court to declare the rule illegal and to stop Missouri from enforcing an emergency Medicaid rule. This rule would have prevented them from getting durable medical equipment (DME). They argued that this emergency rule, which cut off DME coverage for most low-income Medicaid recipients, went against the Medicaid Act's rules about 'comparability' and 'reasonable standards'.

DME includes many medical devices and equipment, like wheelchairs, prosthetics, and hospital beds. Before 2005, Missouri covered DME for all Medicaid recipients. But because of budget problems, Missouri stopped covering DME for most people, except for needy children, the blind, or pregnant individuals. In September 2005, the state issued an emergency rule. This rule brought back coverage for some DME items for all Medicaid recipients. However, it only added coverage for *more* items for those who were blind, pregnant, needy children, or getting home health care. The plaintiffs, who didn't fit these specific groups, could no longer get DME that used to be covered. Instead of challenging the law itself, the plaintiffs argued that the emergency rule wrongly gave DME coverage to blind recipients but not others, which violated federal law.

On September 13, 2005, the court (Judge Whipple) denied the plaintiffs' request to temporarily stop the rule. Judge Whipple thought Missouri's emergency rules probably did not violate the Medicaid Act's 'comparability' rule. He concluded that the plaintiffs could likely get DME through other parts of Missouri's Medicaid program. He also noted that Missouri had asked the federal Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) for permission to provide DME to the blind, but not to others like the plaintiffs. The plaintiffs appealed this decision to the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals.

On June 22, 2006, the Eighth Circuit (Judge Benton) overturned the lower court's decision and sent the case back. The appeals court found that the state's DME rule was likely overridden by the U.S. Constitution's Supremacy Clause. The Eighth Circuit agreed with the lower court that Missouri's DME coverage did not violate the Medicaid Act's 'comparability' rule. After HHS/CMS denied the waiver, Missouri decided to pay for DME for the blind using only state money, not federal funds. This meant it didn't have to follow the federal rule for that specific group. For similar reasons, the court also found that the DME services did not violate the 'reasonable standards' rule. The court also decided that the plaintiffs could not directly sue under Section 1983 to enforce Medicaid's 'reasonable standards' rule.

However, the Eighth Circuit concluded that Missouri's DME rules conflicted with federal rules that put Medicaid's 'reasonable standards' requirement into practice. Therefore, the state rules violated the Supremacy Clause. The plaintiffs had argued that the state rule was unreasonable. They said it didn't provide enough DME services to meet Medicaid's basic goals, and the state's suggested alternative ways to get DME were not good enough. The court agreed, finding that the plaintiffs were likely to win their argument that the state rule was overridden by federal law regarding the 'reasonable standards' requirement. The court explained that since 'likelihood of success on the merits' is just one of four factors for granting a temporary stop order, and the lower court hadn't looked at the other factors, the case needed to be sent back.

On March 2, 2007, Judge Whipple, after getting the case back, ruled in favor of the plaintiffs. He also issued a temporary order to stop Missouri from enforcing its emergency Medicaid rules that had largely cut off the plaintiffs' access to DME through Medicaid. Judge Whipple ordered the state to change its DME program to meet Medicaid's 'reasonable standards' rule, fixing the issue that the Eighth Circuit found was overridden by federal law.

On June 1, 2008, the state (the defendants) told the court that on May 18, 2007, the Missouri legislature had passed a new law. This law covered all medically necessary DME. Because of this, the state asked the court to declare that they were following the court's March 2 order.

On January 23, 2008, Judge Whipple declared that the state was following that order. However, he pointed out that the only thing the court was looking at was whether Missouri's 2005 emergency rules were legal. By getting rid of that proposed set of rules, Missouri obeyed the order. But the court was not deciding if the state's new law from May 2007 met the 'reasonable standards' rule.

Since Judge Whipple found the state was following the March 2, 2007 order, the case was closed.

By getting rid of that proposed set of rules, Missouri obeyed the order. But the court was not deciding if the state's new law from May 2007 met the 'reasonable standards' rule.

On August 29, 2005, seven low-income Missouri residents on Medicaid filed a lawsuit in a federal court in Missouri. They sued the State of Missouri, saying a state rule went against federal law, specifically the federal Medicaid Act and a part of the U.S. Constitution called the Supremacy Clause. Think of the Supremacy Clause like this: if a state law and a federal law disagree, the federal law wins. It's like the federal government's rules are the 'supreme' ones. These residents, with help from groups that work for the public good, asked the court to say the rule was illegal and stop Missouri from using an emergency Medicaid rule. This rule would have stopped them from getting important medical equipment, like wheelchairs or hospital beds, which we'll call DME from now on. They argued this emergency rule, which stopped most low-income Medicaid users from getting DME, went against the federal Medicaid law's rules. These rules say that states must offer 'comparable' benefits (meaning similar benefits for similar groups of people) and meet 'reasonable standards' (meaning they must provide enough benefits).

DME includes many medical devices and equipment, like wheelchairs, prosthetics (artificial limbs), and hospital beds. Before 2005, Missouri paid for DME for everyone on Medicaid. But because of money problems, Missouri stopped paying for DME for most people. Only certain groups, like children in need, people who are blind, or pregnant individuals, could still get it. In September 2005, the state put out an emergency rule. This new rule brought back *some* DME coverage for everyone on Medicaid. But it offered *more* items only to those who were blind, pregnant, needy children, or getting care at home. The people who sued didn't fit into these special groups. So, they couldn't get DME that they used to be able to get. Instead of arguing against the law itself, the plaintiffs said that the emergency rule was wrong because it gave DME to blind people but not to others like them, which they said broke federal law.

On September 13, 2005, the court, led by Judge Whipple, said 'no' to the plaintiffs' request for a temporary order to stop the rule. Judge Whipple thought Missouri's emergency rules probably didn't break the Medicaid law's 'comparability' rule (the one about similar benefits for similar groups). He believed the plaintiffs could likely get DME through other parts of Missouri's Medicaid program. He also pointed out that Missouri had asked federal agencies (like the Department of Health and Human Services, or HHS) for a special permission, called a 'waiver,' to give DME to blind people but not to others like the plaintiffs. The appeals court decided that the state's DME rule was likely overridden by the U.S. Constitution's Supremacy Clause (remember, federal law wins). The Eighth Circuit agreed with the lower court that Missouri's DME coverage didn't break the Medicaid law's 'comparability' rule. After the federal agencies said 'no' to Missouri's special permission (waiver), Missouri decided to pay for DME for the blind using only its own state money, not federal money. This meant that for that specific group (the blind), Missouri didn't have to follow the federal rule. The court also found that the actual DME services Missouri provided didn't break the 'reasonable standards' rule (the one about providing enough benefits). And the court decided the plaintiffs couldn't directly sue under a specific federal law to make sure Medicaid's 'reasonable standards' rule was followed.

However, the Eighth Circuit concluded that Missouri's DME *rules* themselves went against federal rules. The plaintiffs had argued that the state rule was unreasonable. They said it didn't provide enough DME services to meet Medicaid's main goals. They also said that the state's suggested other ways to get DME weren't good enough. The court agreed. It found the plaintiffs were likely to win their argument that the state rule was overridden by federal law when it came to the 'reasonable standards' requirement. The court explained that showing you're 'likely to win' is just one of four things a court looks at when deciding whether to issue a temporary stop order. Since the lower court hadn't looked at the other things, the case needed to be sent back again.

This fixed the problem that the Eighth Circuit said was overridden by federal law.

This new law said it would cover all medically necessary DME. Because of this, the state asked the court to say they were now following the court's order from March 2.

On January 23, 2008, Judge Whipple said that the state *was* following that order. However, he pointed out that the court was only looking at whether Missouri's 2005 emergency rules were legal. By getting rid of that specific set of rules, Missouri obeyed the order. But the court was *not* deciding if the state's *new* law from May 2007 actually met the 'reasonable standards' rule.

They sought summary judgment to definitively establish the illegality of the state's regulation without a full trial, and again requested a preliminary injunction to immediately halt its enforcement. The district court, now bound by the Eighth Circuit's interpretation, granted both. This ruling effectively enjoined Missouri from enforcing the emergency regulation, ordering the state to amend its DME program to comply with federal reasonable-standards requirements, thereby remedying the preemption issue identified by the appellate court.

The state's strategic response came in June 2008. To demonstrate compliance and bring the litigation to a close, Missouri informed the court that its General Assembly had passed new legislation covering all medically necessary DME. The state sought a declaration from the court that it had fulfilled its obligations under the March 2007 order. In January 2008, the court acknowledged the state's compliance, noting that the specific emergency regulations challenged in the lawsuit had been addressed. While the court did not rule on the broader legality of the state's new legislative action, it found that the original legal dispute over the 2005 emergency regulations had been resolved, thus closing the case.

2.transformed_text:
At the heart of this case was a dispute over whether Missouri could restrict access to vital durable medical equipment (DME) for its low-income Medicaid recipients without violating federal law. Seven low-income Missouri residents, relying on Medicaid for health coverage, found their access to essential items like wheelchairs and prosthetics cut off by an emergency Medicaid regulation. They argued this state regulation, imposed due to budget constraints, violated federal Medicaid law's mandate for comparable and reasonable standards of coverage.

After the plaintiffs' initial request for a preliminary injunction was denied by the district court, the case progressed through an appeal to the Eighth Circuit, which reversed and remanded, ultimately leading to a successful motion for summary judgment and injunction on remand.

The district court initially sided with the state, concluding that the emergency regulations likely did not violate federal comparability requirements and suggesting that other avenues for obtaining DME existed. This decision allowed the state's restrictive policy to continue, leaving many vulnerable citizens without necessary medical devices. However, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals, upon review, identified a critical flaw. While agreeing that the state's provision of DME did not violate the Medicaid Act's comparability requirement, the appellate court found that Missouri's emergency regulation was likely preempted by federal law under the Supremacy Clause. This was because the state's limitations directly conflicted with the "reasonable standards" requirement of Medicaid. The Eighth Circuit sent the case back, instructing the lower court to reconsider the injunction in light of this significant preemption finding.

Following this guidance, the plaintiffs successfully pressed their case. The district court, now bound by the appellate court's interpretation, granted both summary judgment and a preliminary injunction. This ruling effectively prevented Missouri from enforcing the emergency regulation, ordering the state to amend its DME program to comply with federal reasonable-standards requirements. To resolve the litigation and demonstrate compliance, Missouri's General Assembly subsequently passed new legislation covering all medically necessary DME. The court then acknowledged the state's compliance, finding that the specific emergency regulations challenged in the lawsuit had been addressed, thereby closing the case and restoring access to essential medical equipment for those who needed it.

original_case_data.name: U.S. v. Virginia
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
On May 4, 1990, the United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division announced, in a letter to the Governor of Virginia, its intent to launch an investigation, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq., into conditions at the Northern Virginia Training Center (NVTC), an institution for individuals with developmental disabilities in Fairfax, Virginia. Five experts from the Department of Justice toured the facility, reviewed policies and procedures, interviewed NVTC staff, and audited reporting and investigation practices.

On April 9, 1991, the Department of Justice announced its findings. The Department of Justice reported that the health and safety of people living at NVTC was at risk for a number of reasons. NVTC employed too few people and inadequately trained those it did employ, which placed residents in danger of unnecessary chexmical and physical restraint. Often mechanical restraints were accompanied by seclusion, which was a fire hazard. Individualized programming for residents was inadequate and recordkeeping deficiencies made it impossible to monitor an individual's progress. In addition, NVTC's medical care, physical therapy, occupational therapy, and medication and side effect monitoring we all inadequate. In addition, NVTC provided insufficient medical care, including medication monitoring and occupational therapy. Recordkeeping made it difficult to track the efficacy of individualized programming and medical care. In closing, the Department of Justice expressed the desire to negotiate a resolution.

Negotiations did not make enough progress and, on May 31, 1994, the Department of Justice threatened to file a CRIPA lawsuit to challenge the constitutionality of conditions at NVTC. In addition to its earlier concerns, the Department of Justice chronicled systematic abuse and neglect at NVTC. For instance, individualized training programs were so inadequate that individuals became seriously sick or died as the result of aggressive, pica, and other self-injurious behaviors. One resident asphyxiated on a rubber glove, while another ate a reported seven cigarettes and one feminine hygiene pad in the span of two days. Similarly, inappropriate feeding techniques and poor nutrition endangered residents' health.

Virginia may have made an effort engage in productive negotiations, but the Department of Justice was not satisfied. On February 8, 1995, the Department of Justice notified the Governor of Virginia that, in addition to being unconstitutional, the conditions at NVTC violated the Americans With Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq., Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. §§ 794, the Social Security Act ("Medicaid"), 42 U.S.C. §§ 1396 et seq., and Virginia law.

On March 4, 1996, the Department of Justice filed a CRIPA lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, challenging conditions at NVTC. The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief to address (1) individualized programming, (2) undue physical restraint and isolation, (3) facility safety, (4) medical care, (5) physical and occupational therapy, (6) medication monitoring, especially for tardive dyskenesia, and (7) staff numbers and training.

On May 21, 1996, the court (Judge Leonie M. Brinkema) refused to consolidate this lawsuit with United States v. Virginia, No. 96-284, U.S. v. Virginia, an action challenging the constitutionality of conditions at a Virginia psychiatric hospital. On May 21, 1996, the court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but stayed its ruling to allow for settlement. On July 18, 1996, the court approved a settlement agreement.

The settlement agreement itself was mostly concerned with procedural elements, such as development of a plan for improvement, compliance deadlines, evaluation, and dismissal. The NVTC plan describes the required compliance. The plan emphasizes the importance of trained staff in the provision of developmental disability services. The plan stated detailed training requirements for direct care staff and incorporated training into almost every solution. For instance, the plan mandated the dismissal of employees who neglected or abused residents. Similarly, the plan sought to reduce the need for restraints by both improving staff development and requiring the interdisciplinary treatment teams' advance approval for the type of restraints to be used for each individual. Thus, both chemical restraints and draconian physical restraint techniques, such as papoose boards, were eliminated. Similar clauses addressed medical care, medication administration and tracking, physical and occupational therapy, abuse and injury reporting and investigations, recordkeeping, functional planning, community placement, and quality assurance.

The parties modified the settlement on May 30, 1997. On August 29, 1997, the Department of Justice inspected NVTC and found it was in compliance with the plan. On June 3, 1998, the court dismissed the lawsuit.
original_case_data.summary_short: On May 4, 1990, the Civil Rights Division of the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) launched an investigation pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. §1997 et seq., into conditions at the Northern Virginia Training Center (NVTC).  On April 9, 1991, the DOJ released their findings; people at NCTC were at risk because of inadequate training of staff and inappropriate chemical and physical restraints.  Negotiations were initiated, but broke down. On March 4, 1996 the DOJ filed a CIRPA lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.  On July 18, 1996, the parties entered a court approved settlement agreement in which NVTC agreed to better train their staff and reduce their need for restraints.  The court dismissed the lawsuit on June 3, 1998.

1.transformed_text:
On May 4, 1990, the United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division announced a CRIPA investigation (42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq.) into conditions at the Northern Virginia Training Center (NVTC), an institution for individuals with developmental disabilities. DOJ experts toured the facility, reviewing policies, interviewing staff, and auditing reporting and investigation practices.

On April 9, 1991, the Department of Justice announced findings indicating significant risks to NVTC residents' health and safety due to insufficient staffing and training, leading to unnecessary chemical and physical restraint, often with seclusion posing a fire hazard. Inadequate individualized programming, recordkeeping deficiencies, and insufficient medical care, including physical/occupational therapy and medication monitoring, were also identified. The Department of Justice sought negotiation.

Negotiations stalled, leading the Department of Justice to threaten a CRIPA lawsuit on May 31, 1994, challenging NVTC's unconstitutional conditions. Beyond prior concerns, DOJ chronicled systematic abuse and neglect, citing inadequate individualized training programs that caused serious illness or death from aggressive, pica, and other self-injurious behaviors, such as a resident asphyxiating on a rubber glove or ingesting cigarettes and a feminine hygiene pad. Inappropriate feeding techniques and poor nutrition further endangered residents' health.

Despite Virginia's negotiation efforts, the Department of Justice remained unsatisfied. On February 8, 1995, DOJ notified the Governor that NVTC conditions violated not only constitutional standards but also the Americans With Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq., Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. §§ 794, the Social Security Act ("Medicaid"), 42 U.S.C. §§ 1396 et seq., and Virginia law.

On March 4, 1996, the Department of Justice filed a CRIPA lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, challenging NVTC conditions. Plaintiffs sought injunctive relief for (1) individualized programming, (2) undue physical restraint and isolation, (3) facility safety, (4) medical care, (5) physical and occupational therapy, (6) medication monitoring, particularly for tardive dyskinesia, and (7) staff numbers and training.

On May 21, 1996, the court (Judge Leonie M. Brinkema) refused to consolidate this lawsuit with *United States v. Virginia*, No. 96-284, a related action concerning a Virginia psychiatric hospital. The court simultaneously granted defendants' motion to dismiss but stayed the ruling to facilitate settlement, which was approved on July 18, 1996.

The settlement agreement primarily established procedural elements for an NVTC improvement plan, covering development, compliance deadlines, evaluation, and dismissal. The plan detailed required compliance, emphasizing trained staff for developmental disability services. It specified detailed training for direct care staff, integrating training into solutions, and mandated dismissal for employees who neglected or abused residents. The plan also sought to reduce restraints by improving staff development and requiring interdisciplinary treatment team approval for individual restraint types, eliminating chemical restraints and draconian physical techniques like papoose boards. Similar clauses addressed medical care, medication administration and tracking, physical and occupational therapy, abuse/injury reporting and investigations, recordkeeping, functional planning, community placement, and quality assurance.

The parties modified the settlement on May 30, 1997. An August 29, 1997 DOJ inspection confirmed NVTC's compliance, leading to the lawsuit's dismissal by the court on June 3, 1998.

3.transformed_text:
The United States Department of Justice successfully resolved its CRIPA lawsuit against the Northern Virginia Training Center, resulting in a comprehensive settlement agreement that mandated significant improvements to resident care and facility conditions, leading to the lawsuit's dismissal upon demonstrated compliance.

*   **Initial Investigation and Findings:** Following a May 1990 CRIPA investigation, the DOJ announced in April 1991 that NVTC conditions posed significant health and safety risks to residents. Findings cited insufficient staffing and training, leading to unnecessary chemical and physical restraint, inadequate individualized programming, recordkeeping deficiencies, and insufficient medical care.
*   **Litigation and Claims:** After stalled negotiations, the DOJ threatened a CRIPA lawsuit in May 1994, detailing systematic abuse and neglect, including inadequate individualized training causing serious illness or death, and inappropriate feeding techniques. By February 1995, the DOJ further asserted violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, the Social Security Act ("Medicaid"), and Virginia law. The lawsuit, filed March 1996 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, sought injunctive relief addressing individualized programming, restraint practices, facility safety, medical and therapeutic care, medication monitoring (e.g., for tardive dyskinesia), and staff levels and training.
*   **Settlement and Remediation:** The court, while initially granting dismissal, stayed its ruling to facilitate settlement. Approved in July 1996, the settlement established a procedural framework for an NVTC improvement plan. This plan mandated trained staff for developmental disability services, specific direct care training, dismissal for neglect/abuse, and reduced restraints by requiring interdisciplinary team approval and eliminating chemical/draconian physical techniques. It also addressed medical care, medication, therapy, abuse reporting, recordkeeping, functional planning, community placement, and quality assurance.
*   **Compliance and Case Closure:** After a modification in May 1997, a DOJ inspection in August 1997 confirmed NVTC's compliance with the settlement terms. Consequently, the court dismissed the lawsuit in June 1998.

On February 8, 1995, the Department of Justice notified the Governor of Virginia that, in addition to being unconstitutional, the conditions at NVTC violated the Americans With Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq., Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. §§ 794, the Social Security Act ("Medicaid"), 42 U.S.C. §§ 1396 et seq., and Virginia law.

On March 4, 1996, the Department of Justice filed a CRIPA lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, challenging conditions at NVTC. The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief to address (1) individualized programming, (2) undue physical restraint and isolation, (3) facility safety, (4) medical care, (5) physical and occupational therapy, (6) medication monitoring, especially for tardive dyskenesia, and (7) staff numbers and training.

On May 21, 1996, the court (Judge Leonie M. Brinkema) refused to consolidate this lawsuit with United States v. Virginia, No. 96-284, U.S. v. Virginia, an action challenging the constitutionality of conditions at a Virginia psychiatric hospital. On May 21, 1996, the court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but stayed its ruling to allow for settlement. On July 18, 1996, the court approved a settlement agreement.

The settlement agreement itself was mostly concerned with procedural elements, such as development of a plan for improvement, compliance deadlines, evaluation, and dismissal. The NVTC plan describes the required compliance. The plan emphasizes the importance of trained staff in the provision of developmental disability services. The plan stated detailed training requirements for direct care staff and incorporated training into almost every solution. For instance, the plan mandated the dismissal of employees who neglected or abused residents. Similarly, the plan sought to reduce the need for restraints by both improving staff development and requiring the interdisciplinary treatment teams' advance approval for the type of restraints to be used for each individual. Thus, both chemical restraints and draconian physical restraint techniques, such as papoose boards, were eliminated. Similar clauses addressed medical care, medication administration and tracking, physical and occupational therapy, abuse and injury reporting and investigations, recordkeeping, functional planning, community placement, and quality assurance.

The parties modified the settlement on May 30, 1997. On August 29, 1997, the Department of Justice inspected NVTC and found it was in compliance with the plan. On June 3, 1998, the court dismissed the lawsuit.

1.transformed_text:
On May 4, 1990, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) informed the Governor of Virginia that it would investigate conditions at the Northern Virginia Training Center (NVTC). NVTC was a facility in Fairfax, Virginia, for people with developmental disabilities. The DOJ launched this investigation under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA). Five DOJ experts visited the facility. They looked at its rules and practices, spoke with NVTC staff, and checked how the center handled reports and investigations.

On April 9, 1991, the DOJ announced what it found. It reported that the health and safety of NVTC residents were at risk for several reasons. NVTC did not employ enough staff, and the staff they had were not properly trained. This put residents at risk of unnecessary chemical and physical restraints. Often, mechanical restraints were used along with isolation, which also created a fire hazard. The personalized programs for residents were not good enough, and poor recordkeeping made it hard to track individual progress. Also, NVTC's medical care, physical therapy, occupational therapy, and monitoring of medications and their side effects were all insufficient. The DOJ ended its report by stating it wanted to work out a solution.

Negotiations did not move forward enough. So, on May 31, 1994, the DOJ threatened to sue NVTC under CRIPA. This lawsuit would challenge whether the conditions at NVTC were constitutional. Besides its earlier worries, the DOJ also documented widespread abuse and neglect at NVTC. For example, personalized training programs were so poor that some residents became very sick or died from aggressive actions, eating non-food items (pica), and other self-harming behaviors. One resident choked to death on a rubber glove, while another reportedly ate seven cigarettes and a feminine hygiene pad in two days. Likewise, improper feeding methods and bad nutrition also put residents' health at risk.

Virginia may have tried to negotiate effectively, but the DOJ was still not satisfied. On February 8, 1995, the DOJ told the Governor of Virginia that the conditions at NVTC were not only unconstitutional but also broke several federal laws. These included the Americans With Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, the Social Security Act (Medicaid), and even Virginia's own laws.

On March 4, 1996, the DOJ officially filed its CRIPA lawsuit against NVTC in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia. The lawsuit aimed to change the conditions at NVTC. The DOJ asked the court to order NVTC to fix problems with: (1) personalized programs for residents, (2) excessive physical restraints and isolation, (3) facility safety, (4) medical care, (5) physical and occupational therapy, (6) monitoring of medications (especially for conditions like tardive dyskinesia), and (7) the number and training of staff.

On May 21, 1996, the court (Judge Leonie M. Brinkema) decided not to combine this case with another one, *United States v. Virginia*, which also challenged conditions at a different Virginia psychiatric hospital. On the same day, the court also agreed to the defendants' request to dismiss the case, but it put this decision on hold to allow the parties to reach a settlement. On July 18, 1996, the court approved a settlement agreement between the DOJ and NVTC.

The settlement agreement mainly focused on how to improve things, setting out steps like creating an improvement plan, deadlines for meeting goals, evaluating progress, and eventually ending the lawsuit. The NVTC plan detailed what the center needed to do to follow the agreement. The plan stressed how important it was for staff caring for people with developmental disabilities to be well-trained. It included specific training rules for direct care staff and made training a part of almost every solution. For example, the plan required firing employees who neglected or abused residents. It also aimed to reduce the need for restraints by improving staff skills and requiring a team of experts to approve any type of restraint before it was used for a resident. This meant that certain chemical restraints and harsh physical restraints, like papoose boards, were no longer allowed. The agreement also included similar rules for medical care, managing and tracking medications, physical and occupational therapy, reporting and investigating abuse and injuries, keeping records, planning for residents' daily needs, helping residents live in the community, and ensuring overall quality.

The parties changed the settlement agreement slightly on May 30, 1997. On August 29, 1997, the DOJ inspected NVTC and confirmed that the center was following the plan. On June 3, 1998, the court closed the lawsuit.

3.transformed_text:
Imagine a federal agency, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ), like a national watchdog for fairness. In May 1990, they announced they would investigate a place called the Northern Virginia Training Center (NVTC) in Fairfax, Virginia. NVTC was a home for people with developmental disabilities, meaning they needed special support to live and learn. The DOJ started this investigation because of a federal law called the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act. Think of it as a law designed to protect people living in places like NVTC. Five experts from the DOJ visited NVTC. They looked at how things were run, talked to the staff, and checked how problems were reported and looked into.

About a year later, in April 1991, the DOJ shared what they discovered. They found that the health and safety of the people living at NVTC were in danger for many reasons. There weren't enough staff members, and the ones who were there didn't have the right training. This led to residents being held back too often, sometimes with medicines or by tying them down, even when it wasn't needed. Sometimes, people were tied down and also kept alone in a room, which was dangerous and even created a fire risk. The special plans for each resident weren't good enough, and bad record-keeping made it hard to see if people were getting better. Also, the medical care, physical therapy (helping with movement), occupational therapy (helping with daily tasks), and how they watched over medications and their side effects were all not good enough. The DOJ finished their report by saying they hoped to find a solution together.

Talks to fix things didn't go well enough. So, in May 1994, the DOJ warned NVTC that they would sue them, using that same Civil Rights Act. This lawsuit would ask if the way people were treated at NVTC was even legal under the U.S. Constitution. Besides the problems they already found, the DOJ also reported a lot of abuse and neglect happening at NVTC. For example, the special training programs were so bad that some residents got very sick or even died because of aggressive actions, eating things that weren't food (this is called pica), and other ways they hurt themselves. One person choked to death on a rubber glove, and another reportedly ate seven cigarettes and a feminine hygiene pad in just two days. It's truly shocking. Also, wrong ways of feeding people and poor food put residents' health in danger.

Even though Virginia might have tried to work things out, the DOJ still wasn't happy with the progress. In February 1995, the DOJ told Virginia's Governor that the conditions at NVTC were not only against the Constitution but also broke several other federal laws. These laws included the Americans With Disabilities Act (which protects people with disabilities from discrimination), a part of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (another law protecting people with disabilities), the Social Security Act (which includes Medicaid, a health program), and even some of Virginia's own laws.

So, in March 1996, the DOJ officially filed their lawsuit against NVTC in a federal court in Eastern Virginia, using that Civil Rights Act again. The lawsuit's goal was to force changes at NVTC. They asked the court to order NVTC to fix problems with: (1) personalized plans for residents, (2) using too many physical restraints and keeping people alone, (3) making the place safe, (4) medical care, (5) physical and occupational therapy, (6) how medicines were watched (especially for side effects like uncontrolled movements, called tardive dyskinesia), and (7) having enough trained staff.

In May 1996, the judge in charge, Judge Leonie M. Brinkema, decided not to combine this case with another one, *United States v. Virginia*, which was about problems at a different mental health hospital in Virginia. On the same day, the court actually agreed with NVTC's request to throw out the whole case. But, the judge put that decision on hold, giving both sides a chance to work out an agreement instead of continuing the lawsuit. In July 1996, the court approved an agreement that the DOJ and NVTC had worked out.

This agreement mainly focused on how to make things better at NVTC. It laid out clear steps: create a plan for improvement, set deadlines for reaching goals, check how things were going, and eventually close the lawsuit. The NVTC plan detailed exactly what the center had to do to follow this agreement. The plan really emphasized that staff caring for people with developmental disabilities needed to be well-trained. It had specific rules for training the staff who directly cared for residents, and training was a key part of almost every solution. For example, the plan said that employees who neglected or abused residents had to be fired. It also aimed to use fewer restraints by making staff better at their jobs. It required a team of experts to approve any type of restraint *before* it could be used on a resident. This meant that certain drug-based restraints and harsh physical restraints, like "papoose boards" (a board used to hold children still), were completely banned. The agreement also had similar rules for medical care, handling and tracking medicines, physical and occupational therapy, reporting and investigating abuse and injuries, keeping good records, planning for residents' daily needs, helping residents live in the community, and making sure everything was high quality.

Both sides made small changes to the agreement in May 1997. In August 1997, the DOJ checked NVTC and confirmed that the center was following the plan. Finally, in June 1998, the court officially closed the lawsuit, meaning the case was over.

1.transformed_text:
On May 4, 1990, the United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division began an inquiry into the Northern Virginia Training Center (NVTC), an institution for individuals with developmental disabilities. This initiative, empowered by the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), sought to uncover and address potential systemic issues affecting residents' well-being.

By April 9, 1991, the Department revealed its findings, which exposed severe risks to the health and safety of NVTC residents. Deficiencies included understaffing, inadequate training, dangerous use of restraints, and insufficient individualized programming and medical care. Recognizing the gravity of the situation, the Department sought to resolve these issues through negotiation, hoping to secure voluntary improvements without further action.

However, these discussions yielded insufficient progress. By May 31, 1994, the Department escalated its approach, signaling its intent to bring a CRIPA challenge. This move was prompted by persistent, systemic abuse and neglect, including tragic instances where residents suffered severe harm or even death due to self-injurious behaviors and poor nutrition. The Department aimed to compel Virginia to rectify these dire conditions through formal means.

To strengthen its position, on February 8, 1995, the Department informed the Governor of Virginia that NVTC's conditions not only violated constitutional rights but also contravened the Americans With Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and other state and federal mandates. This broadened legal basis underscored the comprehensive nature of the facility's failings.

With all attempts at pre-litigation resolution exhausted, on March 4, 1996, the Department formally initiated a federal proceeding. Its purpose was to secure judicial remedies that would compel NVTC to address fundamental deficiencies, including inadequate individualized programming, excessive physical restraint and isolation, safety concerns, and shortcomings in medical and therapeutic care, as well as staff numbers and training. This proceeding represented a direct appeal for intervention to protect vulnerable individuals.

On May 21, 1996, the presiding judge, Leonie M. Brinkema, opted against combining this matter with a separate concern regarding a psychiatric hospital, keeping the focus distinct on NVTC. On the same day, the facility's representatives sought to have the entire matter closed. While the judge initially acknowledged their arguments, she strategically deferred a final decision, creating an imperative for the parties to reach a resolution outside of a full trial. This judicial encouragement led to a comprehensive accord, which was formally approved on July 18, 1996.

The resulting accord served as a detailed blueprint for NVTC's transformation. It outlined specific requirements for improvement, including strict deadlines and methods for evaluation. The plan emphasized the critical role of well-trained staff in providing quality developmental disability services, mandating comprehensive training and even dismissal for neglectful employees. It also aimed to eliminate harsh physical and chemical restraints by improving staff development and requiring advance approval for any restraint use. Similar provisions addressed medical care, recordkeeping, and community placement, all designed to ensure lasting positive change and accountability.

Following minor adjustments to the agreement on May 30, 1997, the Department confirmed NVTC's adherence to the reforms through an inspection on August 29, 1997. With the facility demonstrating compliance, the court concluded its oversight and closed the matter on June 3, 1998, signifying the successful implementation of the necessary changes and the resolution of the initial crisis.

original_case_data.name: T.G. v. Kern County
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: All youth with mental health, behavioral, learning, intellectual and/or developmental disabilities detained between June 5, 2020 and August 31, 2022 at the Kern County, California Juvenile Facilities (Juvenile Hall, Crossroads, and Camp Erwin Owen)
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
This is a case about alleged abuse and failure to provide education to youth with disabilities detained at juvenile detention facilities in Kern County, California. Plaintiffs, represented by Disability Rights California and Disability Rights Advocates, sued Kern County, the Kern County Probation Department, the Kern County Superintendent of Schools, and two individual officials. They alleged violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (RA), the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act (IDEA), and California state law when authorities used excessive force and failed to provide educational services to youth with disabilities in their care. Specifically, plaintiffs alleged use of pepper spray, physical force, prone restraint, and isolation and solitary confinement that disrupted access to educational services, including special education. Furthermore, plaintiffs alleged inadequate mental health, rehabilitative, and reentry supports and services.

Plaintiffs filed a complaint on February 21, 2018 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California before Judge S. Sant Egata. They sought class certification, a declaratory judgment, preliminary and permanent injunctions, a special master, and attorneys' fees. The following month, on March 9, the court stayed the proceedings in order for the parties to enter settlement negotiations. In July 2019 the case was reassigned to Magistrate Judge Jennifer L. Thurston based on the parties' consent. Magistrate Judge Thurston lifted the stay a month later, on August 1, because the parties had settled. On August 30, 2019, the class was certified by consent of all parties. A few months later, on October 1, guardians ad litem were appointed for named plaintiffs.

The settlement defined the class as:

[A]ll youth with mental health, behavioral, learning, intellectual and/or developmental disabilities . . . who are currently detained, or who will be detained during the Monitoring Term (through August 31, 2022), at the Kern County Juvenile Facilities (Juvenile Hall, Crossroads, and Camp Erwin Owen).

The settlement enforced changes in policy and practice at the Kern County juvenile detention facilities pursuant to a Probation Action Plan and a Court Schools Implementation Plan, which included reforms to 1) facility culture and environment, 2) the case management system, 3) programming, 4) training and coordination to develop a safe crisis management system focused on de-escalation, and to work with the Kern County superintendent to integrate ADA accommodations, Individualized Education Programs, Educationally Related Mental Health Services, and other services, 5) surveys for detained youth, families and staff to provide feedback on facility programs and treatment, 6) complaints and grievance procedures, 7) pepper spray and use of force, 8) isolation, seclusion and confinement, 9) specialized staffing, 10) the individualized safety and security program, 11) suicide prevention, and 12) re-entry. The agreement also included monitoring through August 31, 2022.

The court granted preliminary approval of the class settlement on December 4, 2019. 2019 WL 6529083. It granted final approval on June 5, 2020, and awarded $1,758,743.43 in costs and fees to the plaintiffs. 2020 WL 3035199.

Monitoring was paused from May 6, 2020 through March 29, 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. On August 15, 2023, Magistrate Judge Christopher D Baker granted a stipulated request to further extend the term of monitoring to account for delays in implementation due to COVID-19. 2023 WL 5242359. Therefore, the monitor's final report was due May 20, 2024.

As of May 23, 2024, there have been no further developments and the case is presumed closed.
original_case_data.summary_short: Individuals in a juvenile facility filed this class action lawsuit on February 21, 2018 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against Kern County. The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (RA), the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act (IDEA), and California state law when authorities used excessive force and failed to provide educational services to youth with disabilities in their care. On June 5, 2020, the court approved a class settlement that enforced changes in policy and practice at the Kern County juvenile detention facilities. On August 15, 2023, the parties extended the monitoring period through May 2024 to account for delays due to COVID-19. As of May 23, 2024, there have been no further developments and the case is presumed closed.

1.transformed_text:
This case concerns alleged abuse and educational neglect of youth with disabilities detained at juvenile detention facilities in Kern County, California. Plaintiffs, represented by Disability Rights California and Disability Rights Advocates, sued Kern County, its Probation Department, its Superintendent of Schools, and two individual officials, asserting violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act (RA), the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act (IDEA), and California state law. Specifically, plaintiffs alleged authorities used excessive force, including pepper spray, physical force, prone restraint, isolation, and solitary confinement, which disrupted access to educational services, including special education. They further alleged inadequate mental health, rehabilitative, and reentry supports and services.

Plaintiffs filed a complaint on February 21, 2018, in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California before Judge S. Sant Egata, seeking class certification, a declaratory judgment, preliminary and permanent injunctions, a special master, and attorneys' fees. Shortly thereafter, the court stayed proceedings for settlement negotiations. The case was reassigned to Magistrate Judge Jennifer L. Thurston in July 2019 by consent of the parties. Magistrate Judge Thurston lifted the stay a month later, as the parties had settled. On August 30, 2019, the class was certified by consent, and guardians ad litem were appointed for named plaintiffs a few months later.

The settlement defined the class as:
"[A]ll youth with mental health, behavioral, learning, intellectual and/or developmental disabilities . . . who are currently detained, or who will be detained during the Monitoring Term (through August 31, 2022), at the Kern County Juvenile Facilities (Juvenile Hall, Crossroads, and Camp Erwin Owen)."

The settlement mandated policy and practice changes at the Kern County juvenile detention facilities through a Probation Action Plan and a Court Schools Implementation Plan. These reforms addressed facility culture and environment, case management, programming, crisis intervention and de-escalation training, integration of educational and mental health services (including ADA accommodations, IEPs, and ERMHS), youth and staff feedback, grievance procedures, use of force protocols (including pepper spray, isolation, and confinement), specialized staffing, individualized safety planning, suicide prevention, and re-entry services. The agreement also established monitoring through August 31, 2022.

This case involved claims of abuse and not providing proper education to young people with disabilities held in juvenile detention centers in Kern County, California. The plaintiffs, represented by groups like Disability Rights California and Disability Rights Advocates, sued Kern County, its Probation Department, the County Superintendent of Schools, and two specific officials. They claimed these parties violated federal laws like the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (RA), as well as the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act (IDEA), along with California state law. They said authorities used too much force and did not provide educational services to young people with disabilities in their care. Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that using pepper spray, physical force, face-down restraints, and isolation or solitary confinement stopped these young people from getting educational services, including special education. They also claimed that mental health support, rehabilitation, and services to help them re-enter society were not good enough.

The plaintiffs filed their lawsuit on February 21, 2018, in a federal court in California, before Judge S. Sant Egata. They asked the court to certify the case as a class action, declare certain actions illegal, issue temporary and permanent orders to stop harmful practices, appoint a special monitor, and award them legal fees. The next month, on March 9, the court put the case on hold so the parties could try to reach a settlement. In July 2019, with both sides agreeing, the case was moved to Magistrate Judge Jennifer L. Thurston. Judge Thurston removed the hold a month later, on August 1, because the parties had reached an agreement. On August 30, 2019, all parties agreed to certify the case as a class action. A few months after that, on October 1, legal guardians were appointed for the specific plaintiffs named in the suit.

The settlement agreement defined the group of people covered by the lawsuit as:

> All young people with mental health, behavioral, learning, intellectual, or developmental disabilities who are currently or will be held at Kern County's juvenile facilities (Juvenile Hall, Crossroads, and Camp Erwin Owen) during the monitoring period (through August 31, 2022).

The settlement agreement required changes to policies and practices at the Kern County juvenile detention centers, based on a Probation Action Plan and a Court Schools Implementation Plan. These changes included improvements to: 1) the facility's overall culture and environment, 2) how cases are managed, 3) available programs, 4) training and teamwork to create a safe crisis management system that focuses on calming situations down, and working with the Kern County superintendent to include ADA accommodations, Individualized Education Programs (IEPs), mental health services related to education, and other supports, 5) surveys for young people, their families, and staff to give feedback on programs and treatment, 6) ways to make complaints, 7) rules for using pepper spray and other force, 8) rules about isolation and solitary confinement, 9) having specialized staff, 10) individual safety and security plans, 11) suicide prevention, and 12) services to help young people return to the community. The agreement also included a plan to monitor these changes until August 31, 2022.

The court gave its initial approval of the class settlement on December 4, 2019. It then gave final approval on June 5, 2020, and ordered about $1.76 million to be paid to the plaintiffs for their legal costs and fees.

The monitoring period was paused from May 6, 2020, to March 29, 2021, because of the COVID-19 pandemic. On August 15, 2023, Magistrate Judge Christopher D. Baker approved a request, agreed upon by both sides, to extend the monitoring period further. This was to make up for delays in putting the settlement into practice due to COVID-19. As a result, the monitor's final report was due on May 20, 2024.

As of May 23, 2024, no new developments have occurred, and the case is considered closed.
