The plaintiffs filed their lawsuit on February 21, 2018, in a federal court in California, before Judge S. Sant Egata. They asked the court to approve the case as a "class action" (a lawsuit brought by one or more people on behalf of a larger group), to officially declare certain actions illegal, to issue temporary and permanent orders (court commands) to stop harmful practices, to appoint a special monitor (someone to oversee the changes), and to award them legal fees. The next month, on March 9, the court paused the case so both sides could try to reach a settlement (an agreement to resolve the dispute). In July 2019, with both sides agreeing, the case was moved to Magistrate Judge Jennifer L. Thurston. Judge Thurston lifted the pause a month later, on August 1, because the parties had reached an agreement. On August 30, 2019, all parties agreed to officially approve the case as a class action. > All young people with mental health, behavioral, learning, intellectual, or developmental disabilities who are currently or will be held at Kern County's juvenile facilities (Juvenile Hall, Crossroads, and Camp Erwin Owen) during the monitoring period (through August 31, 2022).

The agreement also included a plan to monitor these changes until August 31, 2022.

The court gave its initial approval of the class settlement on December 4, 2019. It then gave final approval on June 5, 2020, and ordered about $1.76 million to be paid to the plaintiffs to cover their legal costs and fees.

The monitoring period was paused from May 6, 2020, to March 29, 2021, because of the COVID-19 pandemic. On August 15, 2023, Magistrate Judge Christopher D. Baker approved a request, agreed upon by both sides, to extend the monitoring period further. This was to make up for delays in putting the settlement into practice because of COVID-19. As of May 23, 2024, no new developments have occurred, and the case is considered closed.

3.transformed_text:
Imagine you're in a civics class, and we're talking about how our legal system works to protect people. This case is a good example. It was about claims that young people with disabilities were mistreated and not given proper education while staying in juvenile detention centers in Kern County, California.

Groups like Disability Rights California and Disability Rights Advocates, acting on behalf of these young people, sued Kern County, its Probation Department, the County Superintendent of Schools, and two officials. They claimed these groups broke federal laws like the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), which makes sure people with disabilities are treated fairly, and the Rehabilitation Act, which says programs getting federal money can't discriminate. They also said these places broke the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), which guarantees students with disabilities get the education they need for free, along with California state law. The lawsuit claimed that authorities used too much force and didn't provide enough educational services to these young people. Specifically, they claimed that things like pepper spray, physical force, holding kids face-down, and putting them alone in a room (solitary confinement) stopped these young people from getting the education they needed, especially special education. They also said the support for mental health, helping them get back on track, and preparing them to return to their communities wasn't good enough.

The plaintiffs filed their lawsuit on February 21, 2018, in a federal court in California. They asked the court to approve the case as a "class action" – that's like when one or a few people sue on behalf of a much larger group who have the same problem. They also asked the court to say officially that what was happening was against the law, to order the county to stop these harmful things, both for a little while and forever, to have a special person watch over things to make sure the changes actually happened, and to make the county pay for their lawyers.

The next month, on March 9, the court paused the case so both sides could try to reach a settlement – that's like an agreement to solve the problem without going to a full trial. In July 2019, with both sides agreeing, the case was moved to Magistrate Judge Jennifer L. Thurston. Judge Thurston lifted the pause a month later, on August 1, because they had reached an agreement. On August 30, 2019, all parties agreed to officially approve the case as a class action. A few months after that, on October 1, legal guardians (people who were legally in charge of the young people named in the lawsuit) were appointed.

The agreement they reached described the group of young people this lawsuit was for:

> All young people who have mental health, behavior, learning, or developmental challenges, and who are or will be staying at Kern County's juvenile centers (like Juvenile Hall, Crossroads, and Camp Erwin Owen) during the time they were watching over the changes (until August 31, 2022).

The agreement said Kern County's juvenile centers had to change their rules and how they did things. These changes were based on plans from the Probation Department and the Court Schools. These improvements covered things like: 1) making the overall atmosphere and environment of the centers better, 2) improving how they handled each young person's case, 3) offering more and better programs, 4) providing training and working together to handle tough situations safely, focusing on calming things down. This also meant working with the Kern County superintendent to make sure they followed the ADA rules, provided IEPs (which are special learning plans for students with disabilities), offered mental health support for education, and other help. The agreement also covered: 5) creating surveys for young people, their families, and staff to share what they thought about the programs and how they were treated, 6) setting up clear ways for people to make complaints, 7) changing the rules about using pepper spray and other force, 8) changing the rules about putting young people in isolation or solitary confinement, 9) making sure there were enough staff with special training, 10) creating individual safety plans for each young person, 11) improving efforts to prevent suicide, and 12) providing services to help young people get back into their communities. The agreement also said someone would watch over these changes until August 31, 2022, to make sure they were actually happening.

The court first approved this class action agreement on December 4, 2019. Then, on June 5, 2020, it gave its final approval and ordered about $1.76 million to be paid to the young people's lawyers to cover their costs.

The time period for watching over the changes was paused from May 6, 2020, to March 29, 2021, because of the COVID-19 pandemic. On August 15, 2023, Judge Christopher D. Baker approved a request from both sides to extend the monitoring period even longer. This was because the COVID-19 pandemic had caused delays in actually making the changes happen. So, the person watching over the changes had until May 20, 2024, to give their final report.

As of May 23, 2024, nothing new has happened, and the case is now considered finished.

2.transformed_text:
This case addressed the critical question of whether Kern County's juvenile detention facilities unlawfully subjected youth with disabilities to abuse and denied them essential educational and mental health services. After advocacy groups, Disability Rights California and Disability Rights Advocates, filed a complaint alleging systemic violations on behalf of detained youth, the parties engaged in settlement negotiations, leading to a comprehensive agreement that the court ultimately approved.

The resulting settlement represented a landmark commitment to systemic reform, outlining extensive changes detailed in a Probation Action Plan and a Court Schools Implementation Plan. These plans addressed critical areas such as facility culture, case management, programming, de-escalation training, integration of special education services, and improved complaint procedures. A key component was the provision for ongoing monitoring, designed to ensure the county's adherence to the agreed-upon changes and sustain the reforms. The court, after careful review, granted preliminary and then final approval to this class settlement, affirming its fairness and adequacy for the vulnerable population it aimed to protect. This final approval also included an award for the plaintiffs' legal costs. Despite challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, which temporarily paused monitoring, the commitment to the settlement's goals remained, leading to an extension of the monitoring period to ensure full implementation. As of May 2024, with the final monitoring report due, this significant case is presumed to have concluded, leaving a legacy of mandated improvements for youth with disabilities in Kern County's care.

3.transformed_text:
Kern County's juvenile detention facilities are now mandated to provide improved care and essential services to youth with disabilities, a crucial victory for advocacy efforts. This outcome stemmed from a challenge by Disability Rights California and Disability Rights Advocates, who asserted that the facilities unlawfully subjected youth with disabilities to abuse and denied them vital educational and mental health services. Through dedicated advocacy, a comprehensive agreement was forged, outlining extensive changes.

This landmark agreement, detailed in a Probation Action Plan and a Court Schools Implementation Plan, ensures systemic reform. It addresses critical areas like facility culture, case management, programming, de-escalation training, integration of special education services, and improved complaint procedures. A key element is ongoing monitoring, designed to ensure the county's adherence to these changes and sustain the reforms. While the process involved court affirmation of the settlement's fairness, the focus remained on securing these vital protections for vulnerable youth. Despite temporary pauses in monitoring due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the commitment to these goals led to an extended monitoring period, ensuring full implementation. As of May 2024, with the final monitoring report expected, this case has concluded, leaving a lasting legacy of mandated improvements for youth with disabilities in Kern County's care.

Factual Consistency: YES
Dimension Check: YES

4.transformed_text:
Young people with disabilities held in Kern County's juvenile facilities faced a grim reality. Instead of receiving the care and support they needed, they were reportedly subjected to mistreatment and denied vital schooling and mental health services. Their days were filled with challenges that kept them from learning and healing.

Seeing their plight, dedicated advocates from groups like Disability Rights California and Disability Rights Advocates stepped forward. They decided to challenge the system, determined to secure a brighter future for these vulnerable youth.

Their persistent efforts led to a groundbreaking agreement. This commitment promised a complete transformation of the facilities, ensuring a more supportive environment, better care, and proper access to education and mental health services. It also established a system of ongoing oversight to guarantee these changes were fully implemented and would last. Even when global events caused temporary delays, the unwavering dedication to these young people ensured the improvements continued. Today, the landscape for youth with disabilities in Kern County's care has fundamentally shifted, leaving a powerful legacy of mandated improvements and hope.

original_case_data.name: B. v. Kinsley
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights filed suit on behalf of the following class: (a) children who are or will be in North Carolina foster care, who are or will be in the custody of a North Carolina county department of social services; (b) with a mental impairment that substantially limits at least one major life activity, or a record of such an impairment; (c) who are unnecessarily institutionalized in a PRTF or who are at serious risk of such institutionalization.
original_case_data.summary:
On December 6, 2022, Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights filed suit on behalf of a class of North Carolina youth in foster care with mental and behavioral health. The plaintiffs filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). The case was assigned to Judge William L. Osteen, Jr. and Magistrate Judge L. Patrick Auld. 

The plaintiffs asserted that the defendants’ actions violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. In particular, the plaintiffs alleged that DHHS was discriminating against children with disabilities in child welfare custody by unnecessarily segregating them from their home communities and placing them in heavily restrictive, and often clinically inappropriate, psychiatric residential treatment facilities (PRTFs). The plaintiffs requested class-wide relief and asked the Court to certify the putative class and award permanent injunctive relief.  

The plaintiffs sought class certification for those meeting the following criteria: (a) children who are or will be in North Carolina foster care, who are or will be in the custody of a North Carolina county department of social services; (b) with a mental impairment that substantially limits at least one major life activity, or a record of such an impairment; (c) who are unnecessarily institutionalized in a PRTF or who are at serious risk of such institutionalization.

On March 6, 2023, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, removing one of the named plaintiffs. Later that month, on March 20, the defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state a claim and lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

The United States filed a statement of interest in support of the plaintiffs' claims on April 21, 2023. The US argued that 1) the plaintiffs did not need opinions from state treatment professionals in order to establish that integrated settings were appropriate; 2) the children in state custody did not need to allege that their custodians chose community-based care; 3) pending state court proceedings about whether children should be placed in PRTFs did not prevent the plaintiffs from bringing these claims of unnecessary segregation; and 4) the plaintiffs had standing to bring claims against DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen denied the defendants' motion to dismiss. 2024 WL 1350071. The Court held that the Plaintiffs had established standing and that their allegations met the requirements of L.C. v. Olmstead. Under Olmstead, community placement is required when: (1) community placement is appropriate; (2) “the transfer from institutional care to a less restrictive setting is not opposed by the affected individual;” and (3) “the placement can be reasonably accommodated, taking into account the resources available to the State and the needs of others with mental disabilities.”

The Court found that on the facts alleged, though some of the plaintiffs were frequently institutionalized, it was because of a lack of community-based alternatives, not because they required institutionalization, so the plaintiffs had still sufficiently alleged community placement was appropriate. Some plaintiffs were not in institutions but were allegedly at serious risk of being institutionalized, which is also covered by Olmstead. Second, the Court held that Olmstead did not require a minor to allege that their custodian requested community placement: the plaintiffs alleged that they desired community-based services, meeting the second Olmstead prong. Third, the Court held that plaintiffs sufficiently alleged that their placement in the community could be reasonably accommodated, stating that any inquiry into the effectiveness of the state’s plan for community-based services was not necessary at the motion to dismiss stage. Finally, the court held that the Plaintiffs’ claims were not barred by issue preclusion based on state court hearings because the state court hearings were based on individual placements and not the systemic failures alleged here. 

This case is ongoing as of April 26, 2024.
original_case_data.summary_short: Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights filed suit on December 6, 2022 in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina on behalf of a class of North Carolina youth in foster care with mental and behavioral health needs against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act by institutionalizing children instead of providing community-based care. On March 29, 2024, the court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss. As of April 2024, the case is ongoing.

1.transformed_text:
On December 6, 2022, Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights initiated a class action in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) on behalf of North Carolina youth in foster care with mental and behavioral health. The case was assigned to Judge William L. Osteen, Jr. and Magistrate Judge L. Patrick Auld.

Plaintiffs asserted DHHS's actions violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, alleging discrimination against children with disabilities in child welfare custody by unnecessarily segregating them from their home communities and placing them in heavily restrictive, often clinically inappropriate, psychiatric residential treatment facilities (PRTFs). Plaintiffs sought class-wide relief, requesting class certification and permanent injunctive relief.

Plaintiffs sought class certification for children in North Carolina foster care under county social services custody, who possess a mental impairment substantially limiting a major life activity (or a record thereof), and are unnecessarily institutionalized in a PRTF or at serious risk of such institutionalization.

Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, removing one named plaintiff, after which defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state a claim and lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

The United States filed a statement of interest supporting plaintiffs' claims, arguing that: 1) plaintiffs did not require state treatment professional opinions to establish integrated settings were appropriate; 2) children in state custody did not need to allege custodian choice of community-based care; 3) pending state court proceedings on PRTF placements did not preclude these unnecessary segregation claims; and 4) plaintiffs had standing against DHHS.

On March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen denied defendants' motion to dismiss, holding plaintiffs established standing and their allegations satisfied *L.C. v. Olmstead*, 2024 WL 1350071. *Olmstead* mandates community placement when: (1) appropriate; (2) not opposed by the affected individual; and (3) reasonably accommodable given state resources and the needs of others with mental disabilities.

Regarding *Olmstead*'s first prong, the Court found plaintiffs sufficiently alleged community placement was appropriate, noting that frequent institutionalization stemmed from a lack of community-based alternatives, not a requirement for institutionalization. The Court also acknowledged *Olmstead* covers plaintiffs at serious risk of institutionalization. For the second prong, the Court held *Olmstead* did not require a minor to allege custodian request for community placement, as plaintiffs' alleged desire for community-based services sufficed. Third, the Court determined plaintiffs adequately alleged reasonable accommodation for community placement, deeming inquiry into the state's plan effectiveness unnecessary at the motion to dismiss stage. Finally, the Court concluded plaintiffs' claims were not issue-precluded by state court hearings, as those addressed individual placements, not the systemic failures alleged in this action.

This case is ongoing as of April 26, 2024.

1.transformed_text:
On December 6, 2022, Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights started a lawsuit. They sued on behalf of a group of North Carolina young people in foster care who have mental and behavioral health needs. The lawsuit was filed in a federal court, the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina, against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). Judge William L. Osteen, Jr. and Magistrate Judge L. Patrick Auld were assigned to the case.

The plaintiffs claimed that DHHS's actions broke the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. Specifically, they alleged that DHHS was unfairly treating children with disabilities in foster care. They said DHHS was unnecessarily separating these children from their home communities. Instead, DHHS was placing them in very restrictive and often unsuitable mental health treatment centers (called PRTFs). The plaintiffs asked the Court to approve their lawsuit as a 'class action' for the entire group and to issue a permanent order to fix the issues.

The plaintiffs wanted the court to officially approve the group for the class action. This group would include: (a) children who are currently or will be in North Carolina foster care, under the care of a North Carolina county social services department; (b) who have a mental condition that significantly affects at least one major life activity, or a history of such a condition; and (c) who are placed in a PRTF without need, or are at serious risk of being placed in one.

On March 6, 2023, the plaintiffs updated their lawsuit filing, removing one of the people originally named. Later that month, on March 20, the defendants asked the court to dismiss the case. They argued that the plaintiffs' claims were not legally sound and that the court did not have the authority to hear the case.

The United States government filed an official document on April 21, 2023, supporting the plaintiffs' claims. The U.S. argued several points: 1) the plaintiffs did not need opinions from state medical experts to show that community settings were suitable; 2) the children in state care did not need to claim that their guardians chose community-based care; 3) ongoing state court cases about placing children in PRTFs did not stop the plaintiffs from suing over unnecessary separation; and 4) the plaintiffs had the legal right to sue DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen rejected the defendants' request to dismiss the case. The Court decided that the plaintiffs had shown they had the legal right to sue. It also found that their claims met the standards set by the Supreme Court case *L.C. v. Olmstead*. According to *Olmstead*, placing someone in a community setting is required if: (1) a community setting is suitable for them; (2) the person needing care does not object to moving from a facility to a less restrictive setting; and (3) the community placement can be managed without too much difficulty, considering the state's available resources and the needs of other people with mental disabilities.

The Court found that, based on the claims, some plaintiffs were often placed in facilities. However, this was due to a lack of community options, not because they truly needed to be in a facility. So, the plaintiffs had still sufficiently claimed that community placement was suitable. Some plaintiffs were not in facilities but were at high risk of being placed in one, which *Olmstead* also covers. Second, the Court ruled that *Olmstead* did not require a minor to claim that their guardian asked for community placement; the plaintiffs stated they wanted community-based services, which met the second part of the *Olmstead* test. Third, the Court found that plaintiffs had sufficiently claimed that their community placement could be managed without too much difficulty. It added that looking into how well the state's plan for community services worked was not necessary at this early stage of the lawsuit. Finally, the court decided that the plaintiffs' claims were not prevented by earlier state court rulings. This was because those state court hearings focused on individual placements, not the larger, system-wide problems alleged in this case.

This case is still ongoing as of April 26, 2024.

Three groups — Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights — filed a lawsuit on December 6, 2022. They sued on behalf of young people in North Carolina's foster care system who have mental and behavioral health needs. The lawsuit was filed in federal court against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). Judges William L. Osteen, Jr. and L. Patrick Auld were assigned to the case.

The groups claimed DHHS's actions violated two federal laws: the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. These laws protect people with disabilities from discrimination and ensure equal access. Specifically, they alleged DHHS was unfairly treating children with disabilities in foster care. They claimed the state was unnecessarily separating these children from their home communities. Instead, DHHS was placing them in highly restrictive mental health facilities, known as PRTFs, which were often not suitable. The plaintiffs asked the court to approve the lawsuit as a "class action," meaning it would represent a large group of people with similar claims. They also sought a permanent court order to fix the problems.

The plaintiffs wanted the court to officially approve the group for the class action. This group would include: (a) children currently or soon to be in North Carolina foster care, under the care of a county social services department; (b) who have a mental condition that greatly affects daily life, or a history of such a condition; and (c) who are unnecessarily placed in a PRTF or are at serious risk of being placed in one.

On March 6, 2023, the plaintiffs updated their lawsuit, removing one of the individuals originally named in the case. Later that month, on March 20, the defendants asked the court to dismiss the case, which means to throw it out. They argued the plaintiffs' claims lacked legal basis and that the court did not have the authority to hear the case.

The U.S. government filed an official document on April 21, 2023, supporting the plaintiffs' claims. The U.S. argued several points: 1) the plaintiffs didn't need opinions from state medical experts to show that community settings were suitable; 2) the children in state care didn't need to claim their guardians chose community-based care; 3) ongoing state court cases about placing children in PRTFs shouldn't stop the plaintiffs from suing over unnecessary separation; and 4) the plaintiffs had the legal standing, or right, to sue DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen denied the defendants' request to dismiss the case. The court decided the plaintiffs had the legal standing, or right, to sue. It also found their claims met the standards set by a key Supreme Court case, *Olmstead v. L.C.* Under the *Olmstead* ruling, placing someone in a community setting is required if: (1) a community setting is suitable for them; (2) the person needing care does not object to moving from a facility to a less restrictive setting; and (3) the community placement can be reasonably managed, considering the state's resources and the needs of other people with mental disabilities.

The court found that, based on the claims, some plaintiffs were often placed in facilities. However, this was due to a lack of community options, not because they truly needed to be in a facility. So, the plaintiffs had still sufficiently argued that community placement was suitable. Some plaintiffs were not in facilities but were at high risk of being placed in one, which the *Olmstead* ruling also covers. Second, the court ruled that *Olmstead* did not require a minor to claim their guardian asked for community placement. The plaintiffs stated they wanted community-based services, which met the second part of the *Olmstead* test. Third, the court found that plaintiffs had sufficiently claimed their community placement could be reasonably managed. It added that looking into how well the state's plan for community services worked was not necessary at this early stage of the lawsuit. Finally, the court decided that earlier state court rulings did not prevent the plaintiffs' claims. This was because those state court hearings focused on individual placements, not the larger, system-wide problems alleged in this case.

The case remains ongoing as of April 26, 2024.

Imagine a few student groups, like your school's debate club or a community service organization, deciding to speak up for others. That's what three groups – Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights – did when they filed a lawsuit on December 6, 2022. They were suing to help young people in North Carolina's foster care system who have mental health challenges or behavioral needs. They took the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) to federal court. Two judges, William L. Osteen, Jr. and L. Patrick Auld, were put in charge of the case.

The groups argued that DHHS was breaking two important federal laws: the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. Think of these laws like rules that make sure everyone, including people with disabilities, is treated fairly and has the same opportunities. Specifically, they said DHHS was treating children with disabilities in foster care unfairly. They claimed the state was unnecessarily taking these children away from their homes and communities. Instead, DHHS was putting them in special mental health facilities called PRTFs. These places were very strict and often not the best fit for the kids. The groups asked the court to make this a "class action" lawsuit. This means one lawsuit would represent a whole group of young people facing similar problems, not just a few individuals. They also wanted the court to issue a lasting order to fix these issues.

The groups wanted the court to officially say "yes" to this class action, including young people who fit certain descriptions. This group would include: (a) Kids who are currently in foster care in North Carolina, or will be soon, and are looked after by a county social services department; (b) Who have a mental health condition that makes everyday life much harder, or have had one in the past; and (c) And who are being put in those strict PRTF facilities without a real need, or are very likely to be put in one.

On March 6, 2023, the groups updated their lawsuit, taking out one of the individual young people they had originally named. Later that month, on March 20, DHHS (the defendants) asked the court to throw out the case entirely. They argued that the groups' claims weren't strong enough legally and that the court didn't even have the power to hear the case.

The U.S. government, like a helpful ally, filed an official document on April 21, 2023, supporting the groups' claims. The U.S. government made several key points: 1) The groups didn't need doctors from the state to say that living in a community setting was okay for these kids; 2) The kids in foster care didn't have to prove their guardians specifically asked for community care; 3) Even if there were other state court cases about placing kids in PRTFs, those shouldn't stop this lawsuit about unnecessarily separating children; and 4) The groups had the legal right to sue DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen said "no" to DHHS's request to throw out the case. The court decided that the groups did have the legal right to sue. The judge also found that their claims fit the rules set by a very important Supreme Court case called *Olmstead v. L.C.* Think of *Olmstead* like a three-part test. It says that states must place people with disabilities in community settings (like group homes or their own homes with support) instead of institutions if: (1) The community setting is right for them; (2) The person agrees to move from a strict facility to a less strict setting; and (3) The community placement can be handled well, considering what the state has available and what other people with mental disabilities need.

The court looked at the claims and saw that some of the young people were often put into those facilities. But this happened because there weren't enough community options, not because they absolutely had to be in a facility. So, the groups had still made a good enough argument that community placement was suitable. Some young people weren't in facilities yet, but they were at high risk of being put in one, and the *Olmstead* rule covers that too. Second, the court said *Olmstead* didn't require a young person to prove their guardian asked for community placement. The groups simply stated that the young people wanted community-based services, which met the second part of the *Olmstead* test. Third, the court found that the groups had made a good enough claim that community placement could be managed well. It also said that at this early stage of the lawsuit, they didn't need to dig into how well the state's plan for community services was actually working. Finally, the court decided that earlier decisions in state courts didn't stop the groups' claims. This is because those state court hearings were about individual placements, not the bigger, system-wide problems the groups were complaining about in this case.

The case is still ongoing as of April 26, 2024.

0.text:
On December 6, 2022, Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights filed suit on behalf of a class of North Carolina youth in foster care with mental and behavioral health. The plaintiffs filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). The case was assigned to Judge William L. Osteen, Jr. and Magistrate Judge L. Patrick Auld. 

The plaintiffs asserted that the defendants’ actions violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. In particular, the plaintiffs alleged that DHHS was discriminating against children with disabilities in child welfare custody by unnecessarily segregating them from their home communities and placing them in heavily restrictive, and often clinically inappropriate, psychiatric residential treatment facilities (PRTFs). The plaintiffs requested class-wide relief and asked the Court to certify the putative class and award permanent injunctive relief.  

The plaintiffs sought class certification for those meeting the following criteria: (a) children who are or will be in North Carolina foster care, who are or will be in the custody of a North Carolina county department of social services; (b) with a mental impairment that substantially limits at least one major life activity, or a record of such an impairment; (c) who are unnecessarily institutionalized in a PRTF or who are at serious risk of such institutionalization.

On March 6, 2023, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, removing one of the named plaintiffs. Later that month, on March 20, the defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state a claim and lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

The United States filed a statement of interest in support of the plaintiffs' claims on April 21, 2023. The US argued that 1) the plaintiffs did not need opinions from state treatment professionals in order to establish that integrated settings were appropriate; 2) the children in state custody did not need to allege that their custodians chose community-based care; 3) pending state court proceedings about whether children should be placed in PRTFs did not prevent the plaintiffs from bringing these claims of unnecessary segregation; and 4) the plaintiffs had standing to bring claims against DHHS.

Almost a year later, on March 29, 2024, Judge Osteen denied the defendants' motion to dismiss. 2024 WL 1350071. The Court held that the Plaintiffs had established standing and that their allegations met the requirements of L.C. v. Olmstead. Under Olmstead, community placement is required when: (1) community placement is appropriate; (2) “the transfer from institutional care to a less restrictive setting is not opposed by the affected individual;” and (3) “the placement can be reasonably accommodated, taking into account the resources available to the State and the needs of others with mental disabilities.”

The Court found that on the facts alleged, though some of the plaintiffs were frequently institutionalized, it was because of a lack of community-based alternatives, not because they required institutionalization, so the plaintiffs had still sufficiently alleged community placement was appropriate. Some plaintiffs were not in institutions but were allegedly at serious risk of being institutionalized, which is also covered by Olmstead. Second, the Court held that Olmstead did not require a minor to allege that their custodian requested community placement: the plaintiffs alleged that they desired community-based services, meeting the second Olmstead prong. Third, the Court held that plaintiffs sufficiently alleged that their placement in the community could be reasonably accommodated, stating that any inquiry into the effectiveness of the state’s plan for community-based services was not necessary at the motion to dismiss stage. Finally, the court held that the Plaintiffs’ claims were not barred by issue preclusion based on state court hearings because the state court hearings were based on individual placements and not the systemic failures alleged here. 

This case is ongoing as of April 26, 2024.

1.transformed_text:
A pivotal legal challenge began on December 6, 2022, when Disability Rights North Carolina (DRNC), the NAACP, and Children's Rights initiated a lawsuit. Their purpose was to address what they perceived as a systemic failure within North Carolina's foster care system: the unnecessary segregation of youth with mental and behavioral health disabilities. They brought their claims against the North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS), arguing that the state was violating federal disability laws—the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act—by placing these vulnerable children in highly restrictive, often inappropriate, psychiatric residential treatment facilities (PRTFs) instead of providing care within their home communities. The plaintiffs sought to represent a broad class of foster children who were either unnecessarily institutionalized or at serious risk of such confinement, aiming for a court order that would compel the state to shift towards more integrated, community-based services.

After a minor adjustment to their initial filing, the state, through DHHS, responded on March 20, 2023, with a strategic move: a motion to dismiss the entire case. This action was an attempt to end the lawsuit prematurely, asserting that the plaintiffs had failed to present a legally viable claim or that the court lacked the authority to hear the matter. Essentially, the state sought to avoid a full examination of its practices and the potential for a broad injunction.

However, the plaintiffs found a powerful ally in the United States government, which filed a statement of interest on April 21, 2023, supporting their claims. This intervention underscored the federal government's view that the plaintiffs' legal arguments were sound, particularly regarding the interpretation of federal disability law and the right of these children to pursue their claims despite the state's procedural objections.

Nearly a year later, on March 29, 2024, the court delivered a significant ruling, denying the state's motion to dismiss. This decision was a crucial victory for the plaintiffs, ensuring the case would proceed. The judge concluded that the plaintiffs had a legitimate right to bring their claims and, critically, that their allegations aligned with the principles established in the landmark *Olmstead* Supreme Court decision. This precedent mandates community placement for individuals with disabilities when three conditions are met: (1) community placement is appropriate; (2) the individual does not oppose the transfer to a less restrictive setting; and (3) the placement can be reasonably accommodated by the state.

The court systematically addressed each *Olmstead* requirement based on the plaintiffs' allegations. First, it found that the plaintiffs had sufficiently alleged that community placement *was* appropriate, noting that even those frequently institutionalized were there due to a lack of community-based alternatives, not because their conditions inherently demanded institutionalization. The court also recognized that *Olmstead* covered those at serious risk of institutionalization. Second, the court clarified that *Olmstead* did not require a minor's custodian to request community placement; rather, the plaintiffs' own alleged desire for community-based services met this prong. Third, the court determined that the plaintiffs had adequately alleged that their placement in the community could be reasonably accommodated, deeming inquiries into the state's existing plans unnecessary at this early stage. Finally, the court rejected the state's argument that prior individual state court hearings barred this federal lawsuit, emphasizing that those hearings focused on individual placements, whereas this case addressed systemic failures in the state's provision of care.

The legal battle continues, with the core issues of systemic segregation now set to be fully litigated.
